comments: I proved the following facts: (a) If (m,n) is a unitary amicable pair such that mod(m,4)= mod(n,4)=2 and 5 doesn't divide m*n then (10*m,10*n) is a unitary amicable pair. (b) If (m,n) is a unitary amicable pair such that m/12 and n/12 are natural numbers and gcd(m/12,12)=gcd(n/12,12)=1 then (3/2*m,3/2*n) is a unitary amicable pair. - _Farideh Firoozbakht_, Nov 27 2005
references: P. Hagis, Jr., Unitary amicable numbers, Math. Comp., 25 (1971), 915-918.
N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..7896 (from Pedersen's website)
J. M. Pedersen, Known Unitary Amicable Pairs
J. O. M. Pedersen, Tables of Aliquot Cycles
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Unitary Amicable Number.
example: (114,126) is a unitary amicable pair: 114 has unitary divisors 1, (2,57), (3,38) and (6,19), apart from 114 itself. Their sum is 126, whose unitary divisors < 126 are 1, (2,63), (7,18), (9,14) whose sum is 114.
mathematica: uDivisors[n_] := Select[Divisors[n], # < n && GCD[#, n/#] == 1 & ]; mate[n_] := If[m = Total[uDivisors[n]]; n == Total[uDivisors[m]], m, 0]; Reap[Do[If[n < mate[n], Print[n]; Sow[n]], {n, 2, 2000000}]][[2, 1]] (* _Jean-FranÃ§ois Alcover_, Jun 12 2012 *)
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_; extended Nov 24 2005
